title: Psalms Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 21.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:1, in what shall the king rejoice?
options: In the land of his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: In thy strength and salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:1 says the king shall joy in thy strength, O LORD, and in thy salvation how greatly shall he rejoice.

questions.question: What has God given the king according to Psalms 21:2?
questions.correctAnswer: His heart's desire
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:2 states that God has given him his heart's desire and has not withheld the request of his lips.

questions.question: What does God set on the king's head as mentioned in Psalms 21:3?
questions.correctAnswer: A crown of pure gold
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:3 says God sets a crown of pure gold on his head.

questions.question: What did the king ask for from God according to Psalms 21:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Life and length of days
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:4 says he asked life of thee, and thou gavest it him, even length of days for ever and ever.

questions.question: What has God laid upon the king according to Psalms 21:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Honour and majesty
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:5 mentions honour and majesty have been laid upon him by God.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 21:6 states that God made the king exceeding glad with his countenance.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:6 confirms God made him exceeding glad with thy countenance.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:7, in whom does the king trust?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:7 says the king trusteth in the LORD.

questions.question: What will God's hand find out according to Psalms 21:8?
questions.correctAnswer: All thine enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:8 states thine hand shall find out all thine enemies.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21:9 describe the fate of the enemies in God's anger?
questions.correctAnswer: As a fiery oven
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:9 says thou shalt make them as a fiery oven in the time of thine anger.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 21:10, God will destroy the fruit and seed of the enemies from the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:10 states their fruit shalt thou destroy from the earth, and their seed from among the children of men.

questions.question: What did the enemies intend against God as per Psalms 21:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Evil and a mischievous device
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:11 says they intended evil against thee and imagined a mischievous device.

questions.question: What will God make the enemies do according to Psalms 21:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Turn their back
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:12 says God shall make them turn their back when He readies His arrows.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 21:13: 'Be thou exalted, LORD, in thine own ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:13 says, 'Be thou exalted, LORD, in thine own strength.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 21:7 states that through the mercy of the most High the king shall be moved.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:7 says the king shall not be moved through the mercy of the most High.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:6, what has God made the king for ever?
questions.correctAnswer: Most blessed
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:6 says God has made him most blessed for ever.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 21, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: The king trusts in the LORD and will not be moved through His mercy
The king relies on his own strength to overcome enemies
The king must avoid prayer and depend on human wisdom
The king is victorious because of his wealth and power
questions.correctAnswer: The king trusts in the LORD and will not be moved through His mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:7 emphasizes trusting in the LORD and relying on His mercy as the foundation for stability and victory. Verses 1 and 6 also affirm rejoicing in God's strength and gladness through His presence.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21 teach us about God's response to prayer and desires?
options: God gives the heart’s desire and does not withhold requests
God ignores the requests of His people
God only answers after long delays
God gives desires only to the wealthy
questions.correctAnswer: God gives the heart’s desire and does not withhold requests
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:2 states that God has given the king his heart's desire and has not withheld the requests of his lips, showing God's faithfulness to answer prayer. This is supported by verses 3-4 which describe blessings and life given by God.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about their role in church service. According to Psalms 21, how can trusting in God's strength encourage them?
options: God’s strength will exalt and empower us to praise and serve
We must rely only on our own abilities
God expects us to do everything perfectly without help
Service is only for the spiritually gifted
questions.correctAnswer: God’s strength will exalt and empower us to praise and serve
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:13 calls for God to be exalted in His strength, which encourages believers to sing and praise His power. This teaches reliance on God’s strength in service rather than self-reliance.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21, what is the significance of God placing a crown of pure gold on the king's head?
options: It symbolizes blessings of goodness and honor from God
It is a sign of human pride and arrogance
It shows the king’s independence from God
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes blessings of goodness and honor from God
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:3 explains that God sets a crown of pure gold on the king’s head, symbolizing His blessings and honor. Verses 5 and 6 further describe the majesty and joy bestowed by God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21 encourage believers to respond to enemies and adversity?
options: Trust God to handle enemies and bring justice
Take revenge personally and seek retaliation
Ignore enemies and avoid confrontation at all costs
Compromise with those who oppose God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to handle enemies and bring justice
questions.explanation: Verses 8-12 describe how God’s hand will find out enemies and destroy their plans, emphasizing reliance on God for justice rather than personal retaliation. This promotes faith and patience in trials.

questions.question: What does Psalms 21 teach about the source of true joy and gladness in life?
options: Joy comes from God's salvation and presence
Joy depends on material wealth and power
Joy is found in avoiding responsibilities
Joy is based solely on human achievements
questions.correctAnswer: Joy comes from God's salvation and presence
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:1 and 6 reveal that the king rejoices greatly in God's strength and salvation, and is made exceeding glad by God's countenance. This shows joy rooted in God’s presence rather than worldly things.

questions.question: How should a Christian parent use Psalms 21 to teach their children about reliance on God?
options: Teach children to trust in the LORD’s mercy and strength
Teach children to depend on their own plans only
Teach children to avoid trusting anyone
Teach children that success comes without God
questions.correctAnswer: Teach children to trust in the LORD’s mercy and strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:7 emphasizes that the king trusts in the LORD and is stable through His mercy, providing a model for teaching children to rely on God in all circumstances.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 21 teaches that God will allow evil plans against His people to succeed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:11 states that evil plans intended against God cannot be performed successfully, showing God's protection over His people.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21 illustrate God’s faithfulness in granting life and blessing?
options: God grants life and length of days forever upon request
God blesses only after multiple sacrifices
God’s blessings are unpredictable and random
questions.correctAnswer: God grants life and length of days forever upon request
questions.explanation: Verse 4 shows God giving life and length of days forever when asked, highlighting His faithfulness to bless according to His will and promise.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment. What does Psalms 21 teach about God’s provision for satisfaction?
options: God makes His people exceeding glad with His presence
questions.correctAnswer: God makes His people exceeding glad with His presence
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:6 states God made the king exceeding glad with His countenance, teaching that true contentment comes from God’s presence and blessing.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21 encourage a Christian’s work ethic and integrity?
options: Trusting in God’s strength brings honor and majesty
Success depends only on human effort
Integrity is unnecessary if results are good
Work should be done to impress others
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in God’s strength brings honor and majesty
questions.explanation: Verses 5 and 7 highlight that God’s salvation brings glory, honor, and majesty, encouraging believers to rely on God’s strength and maintain integrity in their work.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Thine hand shall find out all thine enemies: thy right hand shall find out those that _____ thee."
questions.correctAnswer: hate
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:8 clearly states that God's right hand will find out those that hate Him, showing His protection for the faithful.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21, how should believers respond to God’s blessings and favor?
options: With praise and exaltation of the LORD’s strength
By boasting about their own achievements
By ignoring God's role in their success
questions.correctAnswer: With praise and exaltation of the LORD’s strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:13 commands believers to exalt the LORD in His strength and sing praises to His power, encouraging humility and gratitude.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 21 reveals that God’s wrath will consume His enemies like a fiery oven.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:9 describes God's anger consuming enemies like fire, illustrating His righteous judgment against those opposed to Him.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21 guide believers in dealing with temptation and evil intentions against them?
options: Trust God to frustrate the evil plans and protect His people
Fight evil intentions by returning evil for evil
Ignore the temptation and evil intentions
Try to negotiate with those who intend evil
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to frustrate the evil plans and protect His people
questions.explanation: Verses 10-12 show that God destroys the fruit and seed of enemies and causes them to turn back, teaching believers to trust God’s protection and justice.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 21.

questions.question: In Psalms 21:3, what is the significance of the 'crown of pure gold' set upon the king's head?
options: It symbolizes divine approval and royal authority
It is a metaphor for wisdom given by Solomon
It indicates a temporary earthly reign
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine approval and royal authority
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:3 highlights that God sets a crown of pure gold on the king’s head, symbolizing His blessing and legitimization of the king's authority, reflecting divine approval rather than just earthly wealth.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 21:7 is echoed in the New Testament regarding the believer's security in God?
options: Trusting the LORD ensures one will not be moved
Faith requires constant works to be stable
Human effort is the foundation of security
God's mercy is conditional on sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting the LORD ensures one will not be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:7 states, 'For the king trusteth in the LORD... he shall not be moved,' paralleling New Testament teachings such as in Hebrews 13:5 that stress trusting God for unshakable stability.

questions.question: In Psalms 21:4, the king's request for 'life' and 'length of days' can be seen as a typology of which New Testament concept?
options: Temporal reign as an earthly king
questions.correctAnswer: Eternal life granted through Christ
questions.explanation: The request for 'life' and 'length of days for ever and ever' in Psalms 21:4 foreshadows the New Testament promise of eternal life through Jesus Christ (John 3:16), showing typological development.

questions.question: The phrase 'thy hand shall find out all thine enemies' in Psalms 21:8 uses which literary device?
options: Simile comparing God to a warrior
questions.correctAnswer: Personification of God's hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:8 personifies God's hand as actively seeking enemies, a common Hebrew poetic device to express divine action in human terms.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice is reflected in Psalms 21:3's imagery of a golden crown?
options: Trade of precious metals for peace treaties
Use of crowns in funerary rites
questions.correctAnswer: Royal coronation symbolizing divine kingship
questions.explanation: The crown imagery in Psalms 21:3 aligns with ancient Near Eastern coronation practices where kings were anointed and crowned to signify divine appointment and authority.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21:9's description of enemies as a 'fiery oven' connect to Old Testament imagery elsewhere?
options: It echoes the refining fire metaphor for judgment
It references the destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah
It symbolizes the burning bush seen by Moses
It depicts the fires of the tabernacle sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the refining fire metaphor for judgment
questions.explanation: The 'fiery oven' in Psalms 21:9 recalls prophetic imagery where fire is a metaphor for God's judgment and purification, such as in Malachi 3:2.

questions.question: What is the literary structure evident in Psalms 21 that emphasizes God's blessings and judgment?
options: Chiastic structure balancing blessing and wrath
questions.correctAnswer: Chiastic structure balancing blessing and wrath
questions.explanation: Psalms 21 displays a chiastic structure where the first half focuses on blessings (verses 1-7) and the second half on judgment against enemies (verses 8-13), creating literary balance.

questions.question: In Psalms 21:2, 'Thou hast given him his heart's desire' uses what Hebrew word for 'heart' that often connotes inner being or will?
questions.correctAnswer: Lev (לֵב)
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'Lev' (heart) in Psalms 21:2 represents the seat of desires and will, indicating God fulfills the king’s inner longings.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:11, the enemies 'imagined a mischievous device which they are not able to perform.' How does this connect with Proverbs 19:21?
options: Both emphasize that human plans are subject to God's sovereignty
Both describe the futility of trusting God
Both focus on the wisdom of human devices
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize that human plans are subject to God's sovereignty
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:11 and Proverbs 19:21 align in teaching that human intentions and schemes cannot succeed apart from God's will, underscoring divine sovereignty.

questions.question: The repeated use of 'Thou' in Psalms 21 emphasizes which theological concept?
options: Personal direct address to God highlighting His active role
questions.correctAnswer: Personal direct address to God highlighting His active role
questions.explanation: The frequent 'Thou' pronoun in Psalms 21 highlights the psalmist's personal and direct address to God, emphasizing His sovereign and active involvement in kingly success.

questions.question: What is the significance of the term 'Selah' in Psalms 21:2, and how might it relate to the psalm's liturgical use?
options: It is a musical pause or reflection point in worship
It denotes a call to battle
It means 'Amen' to conclude the psalm
It is a Hebrew word for prayer
questions.correctAnswer: It is a musical pause or reflection point in worship
questions.explanation: 'Selah' in Psalms 21:2 likely signals a pause for musical or meditative reflection during worship, indicating the psalm's use in temple liturgy.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 21:6, the king's exceeding gladness comes from the wealth of his kingdom.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:6 states the king is exceeding glad with God's countenance, showing that his joy is rooted in God's favor, not material wealth.

questions.question: In Psalms 21:12, 'making ready thine arrows upon thy strings' is a metaphor for what kind of divine action?
questions.correctAnswer: Preparation for judgment against enemies
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Psalms 21:12 depicts God preparing for active judgment against those who oppose Him, illustrating divine warfare imagery.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21:13's call to exalt the LORD 'in thine own strength' relate to the theme of God’s omnipotence in the Psalter?
options: It affirms God's supreme power as the basis for praise
It suggests human strength is the source of victory
It implies that God's power is limited
It calls for self-exaltation among the people
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God's supreme power as the basis for praise
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:13 emphasizes praising God for His own strength, underscoring the Psalter's recurring theme of God's omnipotence as the foundation for worship.

questions.question: The phrase 'their seed from among the children of men' in Psalms 21:10 is an example of what biblical motif?
options: Blessing of offspring for the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: Complete destruction of enemies' lineage
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:10's phrase reflects the biblical motif of total judgment, where enemies' descendants are cut off, symbolizing complete eradication.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:1, in what does the king rejoice?
options: In the LORD's strength and salvation
In the favor of his people
In the wisdom of his counselors
questions.correctAnswer: In the LORD's strength and salvation
questions.explanation: The king rejoices in the LORD's strength and salvation as stated in Psalms 21:1. This is consistent with other Scriptures such as Nehemiah 8:10, Habakkuk 3:19, Isaiah 12:2, and 2 Samuel 22:33, which emphasize rejoicing in God's strength and salvation rather than worldly resources.

questions.question: What has God given the king according to Psalms 21:2?
questions.correctAnswer: His heart's desire
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:2 states that God has given the king his heart's desire and has not withheld the request of his lips. This typifies God's gracious granting of the desires of His anointed, as seen also in 1 Kings 3:10-14, Psalm 37:4, James 1:5-6, and John 15:7.

questions.question: What symbol of honor is placed upon the king's head in Psalms 21:3?
questions.correctAnswer: A crown of pure gold
questions.explanation: The passage in Psalms 21:3 highlights that God sets a crown of pure gold on the king's head, symbolizing divine approval and honor. This imagery aligns with other biblical references such as 2 Timothy 4:8, Revelation 4:4, Isaiah 62:3, and 1 Corinthians 9:25, where crowns represent eternal reward and glory.

questions.question: Psalms 21:4 says the king asked God for life. What was the length of life given?
options: Length of days forever and ever
questions.correctAnswer: Length of days forever and ever
questions.explanation: The text in Psalms 21:4 states the king asked for life and was granted length of days forever and ever. This reflects an eschatological hope of eternal life. Similar promises of eternal life appear in John 3:16, Psalm 23:6, Daniel 12:2, and Revelation 21:4.

questions.question: What does Psalms 21:5 say about the king's glory?
options: His glory is great in God's salvation
His glory comes from his military victories
His glory depends on his wealth
His glory is in the praises of men
questions.correctAnswer: His glory is great in God's salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:5 teaches that the king's glory is great in God's salvation and that God has put honor and majesty upon him. This affirms that true glory comes from divine salvation, consistent with Romans 11:36, 1 Corinthians 1:31, Isaiah 42:8, and Philippians 2:9-11.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:6, what has God made the king?
questions.correctAnswer: Most blessed forever
questions.explanation: The verse Psalms 21:6 declares that God has made the king most blessed forever and has made him exceedingly glad by His countenance. This reflects the blessing and joy that come from God's presence, as supported by Psalm 16:11, Proverbs 10:22, Ephesians 1:3, and Psalm 84:4.

questions.question: What fact about the king's trust is emphasized in Psalms 21:7?
options: The king trusts in the LORD and shall not be moved
The king trusts in his army and plans
The king trusts in his wisdom and counsel
The king trusts in his kingdom's wealth
questions.correctAnswer: The king trusts in the LORD and shall not be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:7 highlights that the king trusts in the LORD and through the mercy of the Most High he will not be moved. This trust in divine mercy is a key biblical theme, seen in Psalm 62:6, Isaiah 26:3, Proverbs 3:5-6, and Hebrews 13:5-6.

questions.question: Who does God's hand find out according to Psalms 21:8?
options: All His enemies and those who hate Him
questions.correctAnswer: All His enemies and those who hate Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:8 states that God's hand will find out all His enemies and His right hand will find those who hate Him, indicating divine justice against opposition. This theme appears in Exodus 15:6, Nahum 1:2-3, Romans 12:19, and Psalm 94:1-2.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Psalms 21:9 to describe the fate of God's enemies?
options: They shall be like a fiery oven consumed by fire
They shall be swallowed by the sea
They shall be scattered like chaff
They shall be covered with darkness
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be like a fiery oven consumed by fire
questions.explanation: The passage in Psalms 21:9 uses the imagery of a fiery oven to express God's wrath consuming His enemies. This metaphor is consistent with Deuteronomy 4:24, Isaiah 66:15-16, Malachi 4:1, and Revelation 20:9-10 which depict God's purifying and consuming judgment by fire.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:10, what will happen to the fruit and seed of God's enemies?
options: They will be destroyed from the earth
They will be scattered among nations
They will become fruitful in exile
questions.correctAnswer: They will be destroyed from the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:10 states that God will destroy their fruit from the earth and their seed from among the children of men, indicating the complete eradication of their lineage. This is consistent with passages like Genesis 6:7, Malachi 4:3, Psalm 109:13, and Matthew 13:40-42 concerning judgment and removal of the wicked.

questions.question: What was the intention of the enemies against God as described in Psalms 21:11?
options: They intended evil and imagined a mischievous device
They desired to worship God sincerely
They wanted to build a temple
questions.correctAnswer: They intended evil and imagined a mischievous device
questions.explanation: The enemies intended evil against God and imagined a mischievous device which they could not perform, as stated in Psalms 21:11. This reveals the futility of rebellion against God, echoed in Proverbs 19:21, Jeremiah 29:11, Romans 8:28, and Psalm 2:1-4.

questions.question: According to Psalms 21:12, what will God do to those who oppose Him?
options: Make them turn their back by readying His arrows against them
questions.correctAnswer: Make them turn their back by readying His arrows against them
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:12 describes God making the enemies turn their back when He readies His arrows upon the strings against them, symbolizing divine judgment and defeat. This is consistent with Psalm 7:12, Isaiah 49:2, Luke 1:51, and Romans 16:20 regarding God's sovereign defense of His people.

questions.question: What is the response of the faithful to God's strength in Psalms 21:13?
options: They will sing and praise His power
They will build altars of stone
questions.correctAnswer: They will sing and praise His power
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:13 calls for God to be exalted in His strength so that the faithful will sing and praise His power. This response of worship and praise aligns with Exodus 15:1-2, Psalm 29:1-2, Ephesians 5:19-20, and Revelation 5:12-13.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most prominently displayed in Psalms 21:7 regarding the king's stability?
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy of the Most High
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:7 emphasizes the king's trust in the LORD and that through the mercy of the Most High he shall not be moved. This highlights God's attribute of mercy as the foundation of stability and security, supported by Exodus 34:6, Lamentations 3:22-23, Ephesians 2:4-5, and Titus 3:5.

questions.question: How does Psalms 21:4 relate to Christian eschatology?
options: It promises eternal life, foreshadowing resurrection and eternal salvation
It predicts temporal prosperity for the king
It describes a physical reign on earth only
It focuses on the mortality of the king's descendants
questions.correctAnswer: It promises eternal life, foreshadowing resurrection and eternal salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 21:4 mentions the king asking for life and God granting length of days forever and ever, which Christians interpret as a foreshadowing of eternal life through resurrection and salvation in Christ. Supporting scriptures include John 11:25-26, 1 Corinthians 15:51-57, Daniel 12:2, and Revelation 21:3-4.
